data.title: Musicians Born in 1902
data.meta_description: Birthdays in music in 1902. See which composers, musicians, pop stars and rockers were born in 1902 or search by date or keyword.
data.text:
Preston Jackson [James Preston McDonald], American jazz trombonist (Preservation Hall Jazz Band), born in New Orleans, Louisiana (d. 1983)

Pierre Palla, Dutch pianist and organist, born in Venlo, Netherlands (d. 1968)

Mark Brunswick, American composer, born in New York City (d. 1971)

Gret Palucca, German dancer and choreographer (Silent Song), born in Munich, Germany (d. 1993)

Rudolf Bing, Austrian-born opera impresario (NY Metropolitan Opera manager, 1950-72), born in Vienna, Austria (d. 1997)

Maurice Duruflé, French organist (St. Etienne-du-Mond, 1929-75), composer (Requiem, Op. 9), and teacher (Paris Conservatory, 1943-70), born in Louviers (d. 1986)

Louis "Putney" Dandridge American jazz pianist and singer (Heatin' Up Harlem), born in Richmond, Virginia (d. 1946)

Evelyn Danzig [Levine], American songwriter ("Scarlet Ribbons"), born in Waco, Texas (d. 1996)

Benny Waters, American jazz saxophonist & clarinetist, born in Baltimore, Maryland (d. 1998)

Carlo Borbolla, Cuban pianist, organist, and composer, born in Manzanillo, Cuba (d. 1990)

Langston Hughes

American poet (Weary Blues), playwright (Mulatto), and librettist (Troubled Island), born in Joplin, Missouri

Bronislaw Kaper, Polish-American Academy Award-winning film composer (Green Dolphin Street; Lili; The Brothers Karamazov), born in Warsaw, Poland (d. 1983)

George Brunies, American musician, born in New Orleans, Louisiana (d. 1974)

Blanche Calloway, American jazz vocalist, bandleader (Twelve Clouds of Joy), civil rights activist, and broadcaster, born in Rochester, New York (d. 1978)

Jack Pettis, American jazz saxophonist and bandleader, born in Ehrmandale, Indiana (d. 1963)

William D. Revelli, American bandleader, born in Spring Gulch, Colorado (d. 1994)

Valentin Ruiz Aznar, Spanish choirmaster, composer, and priest, born in Borja, Zaragoza, Spain (d. 1972)

Fred Scott, American actor and singing cowboy, known as "The Silvery-Voiced Buckaroo" (Melody of the Plains), born in Fresno, California (d. 1991)

John Bubbles, American rhythm tap dancer (No Maps on My Taps), born in Louisville, Kentucky (d. 1986)

Bob Scholte, Dutch vocalist, born in Amsterdam, Netherlands (d. 1983)

Rudolf Moralt, German conductor (Vienna State Opera, 1940-58), born in Munich, Germany (d. 1958)

Edward "Son" House, American delta blues singer-songwriter and guitarist ("Walking Blues"; "Preachin' The Blues"), born in Lyons, Mississippi (d. 1988)

Ellin Berlin (née MacKay), American heiress, writer (Lace Curtain), and second wife of songwriter Irving Berlin (muse for his songs "Always" and "Remember"), born in Roslyn, New York (d. 1988)

Sten Broman, Swedish composer and actor, born in Uppsala, Uppsala län, Sweden (d. 1983)

Jaromír Vejvoda, Czech composer (Beer Barrel Polka), born in Zbraslav, Czech Republic (d. 1988)

Mar 28 Paul Godwin, Polish-Dutch violinist, born in Sosnowitz, Russian Empire (d. 1982)

William Walton, British composer (Troilus & Cressida; Belhazzar's Feast), born in Oldham, Lancashire, England (d. 1983)

Ted Heath, British jazz trombonist, composer, and big band bandleader, born in Wandsworth, London, England (d. 1969)

Danilo Svara, Slovenian composer, born in San Giuseppe, Trieste, Italy (d. 1981)

Henri Garat, French actor and singer (Les dieux s'amusent; Congress Dances), born in Paris, France (d. 1959)

Apr 3 Siguringi Eirikur Hjorleifsson, Icelandic composer, born in Bergskot, Grindavík, Iceland (d. 1975)

James "Rosy" McHargue, American jazz clarinetist, and vocalist (Ted Weems Orchestra; The Wolverines), born in Danville, Illinois (d. 1999)

Elmer Feldcamp, American big band baritone vocalist, saxophonist, and clarinetist (Freddy Martin Orchestra), born in Newark, New Jersey (d. 1938)

Apr 8 Josef Krips, Austrian conductor (London Symphony, 1950-54; Buffalo Philharmonic, 1954-63; San Francisco Symphony, 1964-70), born in Vienna, Austria (d. !974)

František Suchý, Czech oboist and composer (Moravian Wind Quintet), born in Libina, Bohemia, Austro-Hungarian Empire (d. 1977)

Del Porter, American jazz singer (Foursome - "Walkin' My Baby Back Home"; Spike Jones and His City Slickers - "Der Fuehrer's Face"), born in Newberg, Oregon (d. 1977)

Anton Beuving, Dutch lyricist (Ketelbinkie), born in Rotterdam, Netherlands (d. 1977)

Veselin Stoyanov, Bulgarian composer and pedagogue, born in Shumen, Bulgaria (d. 1969)

Reuben "Rube" Bloom, American pianist, arranger, bandleader (The Bayou Boys), songwriter ("Fools Rush In (Where Angels Fear to Tread)"; "Give Me the Simple Life"), born in New York City (d. 1976)

Theodore Chanler, American composer, born in Newport, Rhode Island (d. 1961)

André-François Marescotti, Swiss organist and composer, born in Carouge, Switzerland (d. 1995)

Apr 30 Rudolf Wittelsbach, Swiss pianist and composer, born in Constantinople, Turkey (d. 1972)

Hugo Friedhofer, American composer, born in San Francisco, California (d. 1981)

Cvjetko Rihtman, Bosnian composer, born in Rijeka, Croatia (d. 1989)

Jan Kiepura, Polish vocalist and actor (Her Wonderful Lie; Give Us This Night), born in Sosnowiec, Poland (d. 1966)

John Vincent, American composer, born in Birmingham, Alabama (d. 1977)

Meredith Willson, American composer for stage (The Music Man), and screen (The Great Dictator; Little Foxes), born in Mason City, Iowa (d. 1984)

Mark Lothar [Lothar Hundertmark], German composer (The Story of the Lazy Bear), born in Berlin, Germany (d. 1985)

Helvi Leiviskä, Finnish composer, born in Helsinki, Finland (d. 1982)

Celius Dougherty, American pianist and composer, born in Glenwood, Minnesota (d. 1986)

Billy Mayerl, British pianist, music hall songwriter, theatre composer (Marigold), music publisher, and teacher (School of Syncopation), born in London (d. 1959)

May 31 Henk Schaer [Hendricus Schaareman], Dutch actor (Majoor Barbara; Lijmen), born in Delft, Zuid-Holland, Netherlands (d. 1982)

May 31 Ralph Wood, British contemporary classical composer, born in London, England (d. 1957)

Avraham Daus, Israeli composer, born in Berlin. Germany (d. 1974)

Jun 6 Jimmie Lunceford, American swing jazz saxophonist and bandleader (Rhythm Is Our Business; For Dancers Only), born in Fulton, Mississippi (d. 1947) [1] [2]

Nehemiah "Skip" James, American Delta blues singer, guitarist and piano player ("I'm So Glad"), born in Bentonia, Mississippi (d. 1969)

Gaston Brenta, Belgian composer, born in Brussels, Belgium (d. 1969)

Vissarion Yakovlevich Shebalin, Soviet composer, born in Omsk, Russia (d. 1963)

Sammy Fain, American popular music composer, born in New York City (d. 1989)

Guy Lombardo, Canadian-American orchestra leader (Auld Lang Syne), born in London, Ontario, (d. 1977)

Wilhelm Maler, German composer, born in Heidelberg, Germany (d. 1976)

Antonia Brico, Dutch-American conductor and pianist, born in Rotterdam, Netherlands (d. 1989)

Jun 26 Hugues Cuénod, Swiss tenor and musical educator, born in Corseaux-sur-Vevey, Switzerland (d. 2010)

Richard Rodgers

American composer, mostly for theater (Rodgers & Hart - "Pal Joey"; "Babes In Arms"; Rodgers & Hammerstein - "Oklahoma!"; "South Pacific"; "The King And I"; "The Sound Of Music") and 1st EGOT (Emmy; Grammy; Oscar; and Tony awards winner), born in New York City

George Murphy

American politician (US Senator from California, 1965-71), actor and dancer (MGM Parade), born in New Haven, Connecticut

James McCartney, British cotton salesman, amateur musician, and father of Beatle Paul McCartney, born in Everton, Liverpool, England (d. 1976)

(Theodore Childress) "Chill" Wills, American pop baritone singer (Avalon Boys), and actor (The Alamo; Rounders), born in Seagoville, Texas (d. 1978)

Jul 18 Karel Mengelberg, Dutch composer and conductor, born in Utrecht, Netherlands (d. 1984)

(William) "Buster" Bailey, American jazz clarinetist (WC Handy; King Oliver's Creole Jazz Band; Fletcher Henderson; Noble Sissle; John Kirby), and bandleader, born in Memphis, Tennessee (d. 1967)

Jimmy Kennedy, Irish singer-songwriter ("Teddy Bears' Picnic"; "My Prayer"), born in Omagh, Ireland (d. 1984)

Vladimir Nikolayevich Kryukov, Russian composer, born in Moscow, Russian Empire (d. 1960)

Walter Burle Marx, Brazilian pianist and composer, born in São Paulo, Brazil (d. 1990)

Hans Chemin-Petit, German composer, born in Potsdam, Brandenburg, Germany (d. 1981)

Gus Aiken, American jazz and blues trumpeter (Jenkins Orphanage Band), born in Charleston, South Carolina (d. 1973)

Ray Block, French orchestra leader (Ed Sullivan, Jackie Gleason), born in Imperial Territory of Alsace-Lorraine, German Empire (d. 1982)

Michal Vilec, Slovak composer, born in Bardejovská Nová Ves, Austria-Hungary (d. 1979)

Zino Francescatti, French violinist (New York Philharmonic, 1939), born in Marseille, France (d. 1991)

Bartoes [Albertus J. Wijstma], Dutch singer and cabaret performer, born in Amsterdam, Netherlands (d. 1976)

Stefan Boleslaw Poradowski, Polish composer (Double Bass Concerto), born in Wloclawek (d. 1967)

Julius Kalaš, Czech composer (Nepokořenĺ -The Proud Ones), born in Prague, Kingdom of Bohemia (now Czech Republic) (d. 1967)

Renato Fasano, Italian composer, born in Naples, Kingdom of Italy (d. 1979)

Stefan Wolpe, German composer (Zeus & Elidco), born in Berlin, Germany (d. 1972)

Herbert Menges, English composer, born in Hove, East Sussex, England (d. 1972)

Arnold Maria Walter, Canadian composer, born in Hanušovice, Moravia, Austria-Hungary (d. 1973)

Alice Tully, American singer and arts patroness (Carnegie Hall), born in Corning, New York (d. 1993)

Giorgos Papasideris Greek country singer, composer and lyricist, born in Salamis Island, Greece (d. 1977)

Jeno Takacs, Austrian composer, born in Cinfalva, Hungary (d. 2005)

Mihovil Logar, Serbian composer (A Would-be Lady), born in Rijeka, Croatia (d. 1998)

William Edmonson, American bass harmony and gospel vocalist (Southernaires), radio, stage and screen actor (Thirty Years Later), born in Spokane, Washington (d. 1979)

Hilarion Rubio, Filipino composer, born in Bacoor, Cavite (d. 1985)

Otmar Nussio, Swiss conductor and composer (Boccaccio Suite), born in Grossetto, Italy; (d. 1990)

Oct 23 Otto J. Gombosi, Hungarian-American musicologist, born in Budapest, Hungary (d. 1955)

Eddie Lang [Salvatore Massaro], American jazz guitarist known as the "father of jazz guitar", born in Philadelphia, Pennsylvania (d. 1933)

Armin Kaufmann, Austrian composer, born in Bukowina, Austro-Hungarian Empire (now Romania) (d. 1980)

Eugen Jochum, German conductor (Hamburg Orchestra, 1934-49; Bavarian Radio Symphony, 1949-61), born in Babenhausen, Augsburg, German Empire (d. 1987)

Antonio Maria Valencia, Colombian composer, born in Cali, Colombia (d. 1952)

Marcel Boereboom, Belgian musicologist, born in Stalhille, Jabbeke, Belgium (d. 1985)

Barbara Giuranna, Italian pianist and composer, born in Palermo, Italy (d. 1998)

Emanuel Feuermann, American cellist (Chicago Symphony), born in Kolomyja, Galicia, Austro-Hungarian Empire (now Kolomyia, Ukraine) (d. 1942)

Nov 22 Ethel Smith [Goldsmith], American pop and Latin style Hammond organist ("Tico Tico", "Monkey on a String"), born in Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania (d. 1996)

Giuseppe Savagnone, Italian composer, born in Palermo, Italy (d. 1984)

Miroslav Ponc, Czech composer, born in Vysoké Mýto (d. 1976)

Virgilio Mortari, Italian composer, born in Passirana, Italy (d. 1993)

Paul Kurzbach, German composer, born in Hohndorf, Germany (d. 1997)

Viola Wells [Evans], American jazz, blues, and gospel singer, born in Newark, New Jersey (d. 1984)

Dusolina Giannini, Italian-American dramatic soprano (New York Metropolitan Opera, 1935-42), and teacher, born in Philadelphia, Pennsylvania (d. 1986)

Dec 19 Leonard Hirsch, Irish violinist and orchestra leader (RAF Symphony Orchestra), born in Dublin (d. 1995) [1]

Dec 19 Sol Hoʻopiʻi [Kaʻaiʻai], Native Hawaiian acoustic and electric lap steel guitar virtuoso, born in Honolulu, Oahu, Territory of Hawaii (d. 1953)

Peetie Wheatstraw [William Bunch], American blues singer, songwriter, and piano player, born in Cotton Plant, Arkansas (d. 1941)

Ferenc Szabó, Hungarian composer (Lúdas Matyi, Légy jó mindhalálig), born in Budapest, Hungary (d. 1969)

Lionel Daunais, Quebec singer and composer, born in Montreal, Quebec (d. 1982)

About 1902

How Old? 121 or 122 years old

Generation: Greatest Generation

Chinese Zodiac: Ox (Feb 19, 1901 - Feb 7, 1902),

Tiger (Feb 8, 1902 - Jan 28, 1903)
